bibl.title: Letter from George A. Kellogg to Morris Fishbein, July 22, 1941

div1.p: Kellogg describes to Fishbein the possibilities of including a plate of Cornwell's painting in Hench's article for the journal "Hygeia."

div1.head: Letter from George A. Kellogg to Morris Fishbein, July 22, 1941
div1.opener:
cc to D G. Withington, Phila.
cc to Dr. P.S. Hench, Mayo Clinic
July 22, 1941
Dr. Morris Fishbein
Editor, JOURNAL of the
AMERICAN MEDICAL ASSOCIATION
535 North Dearbora Street
Chicago, Illinois
Dear Dr. Fishbein:
div1.p:
Dr. P. S. Hench has written me that you have accepted
his article on Yellow Fever for publication in HYGEIA at an
early date. Also that you wish to use the new Cornwell
painting, “Conquerors of Yellow Fever” as an illustration.

I am enclosing a couple of pages from the New York Sunday
MIRROR which gives some idea of the color scheme of the paint-
ing even though it is only a newspaper reproduction.

Of course the MIRROR is not purchased to any extent by
physicians and others in whom we are directly interested. It
does, however, aid in the educational job for the general
public, which was one of our motives in sponsoring the series.

Dr. Hench suggested that we might be willing to supply
you with inserts in 4-color process. It is possible that we
might do this but I am afraid that it would delay the publica-
tion of the article beyond the date which you may have schedul-
ed. We could not possibly have inserts before October 1. How-
ever, we can supply you with 4-color process plates of a suit-
able size a little before September 1st or a black and white
plate at any time.

It is my understanding that Dr. Hench's introductory re-
marks on Cornwell and the painting will be used as an explana-
tory note covering the use of the Cornwell painting.

Will it be possible for us to purchase reprints in quan-
tity after the article has appeared in HYGEIA? We are planning
to give to physicians and hospitals approximately 25,000 large
4-color reproductions of the painting over a period of the next
two or three years. I should like to have a reprint of Dr.
Hench's illustrated article with additional halftones (no design-
ated in the reprint) on the development of the painting, to give
with each picture presented to physicians.

At least 12,000 of our large reproductions of the
painting will go to physicians and hospitals during the
months of October, November, and December. You can there-
fore understand my interest in seeing the publication day
for the article placed at as early a date as is convenient
to you.

If you can use 4-color process plates of the painting
will you kindly let me know at your earliest convenience.
I will push the engraver who is now working on them for the
earliest possible delivery. If inserts or a black and white
plate are your preference, please don't hesitate to ask for
them.
div1.closer:
Cordially yours, George A. Kellogg GAK:L
